config.question: Which of the following resulted in a growing regional mentality during the rapid expansion of America’s boundaries?

answer_3.response: Before 1820, the prosperity of the United States depended primarily on agriculture and trade. Jeffersonian America was by no stretch of the imagination an industrial economy. Most of the population—84 percent in 1810—was directly involved in agriculture. Southerners concentrated on the staple crops of tobacco, rice, and cotton, which they sold on the European market. In the North, people generally produced livestock and grain.
